results.title: Florence
results.creator_credit: Ken Wong, Mountains and Kamina Vincent
results.brief_description:
Expertly blending the visual novel and gaming genres, Florence illustrates one year in the life of a young woman in Melbourne as she falls in love, breaks her daily routine and follows her creative passion.

Developed by Australian craft games studio Mountains, Florence uses innovative gameplay mechanics to represent social interactions. The emotions of the poignant narrative are rendered through tapping and swiping minigames, making them all the more touching.
results.description:

results.title: TV miniatures
results.credit_line:
Designed by Graham McGuffie
Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: These six miniature dioramas reflect how home interiors changed to make way for TV across different decades, representing the common places people watched their favourite stories unfold on-screen.

constellations_primary.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_primary.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

results.description: Television didn’t just change the way we see the world; it changed the look and layout of our homes. Since TV arrived in Australia in the 1950s, how and where we watch TV evolved alongside its form and function. These six miniature dioramas, designed by Graham McGuffie and handmade by Emily Boutard, reflect how home interiors changed to make way for TV across different decades, representing the common places people watched their favourite stories unfold on-screen.
description_for_label: Television didn’t just change the way we see the world; it changed the look and layout of our homes. Since TV arrived in Australia in the 1950s, how and where we watch TV evolved alongside its form and function. These six miniature dioramas, designed by Graham McGuffie and handmade by Emily Boutard, reflect how home interiors changed to make way for TV across different decades, representing the common places people watched their favourite stories unfold on-screen.

results.title: [Big Melbourne]
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Wallhead and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: Possible State Film Centre production. Shows a woman and her son on a journey through Melbourne’s central business district, including Flinders Street train station, St Paul’s Cathedral, shopping at Myer. Also features footage of ships and boats.

results.title: Videogames and Us
results.brief_description: Since videogames were first invented in laboratories, our relationship to play has evolved. From arcades and the first home consoles to today’s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, how we interpret and experience vieogames has changed alongside us.

constellations_other.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_other.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

results.description: Play is an essential part of who we are as individuals and as a collective. Since videogames were first invented by scientists in laboratories, our relationship to play has come a long way. From arcades and the first home consoles to today’s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, videogames have evolved dramatically and so have we. How we interpret and experience videogames, and the communities and cultures spawned from them, reveals much about how society has shifted in the past five decades.
description_for_label: Play is an essential part of who we are as individuals and as a collective. Since videogames were first invented by scientists in laboratories, our relationship to play has come a long way. From arcades and the first home consoles to today’s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, videogames have evolved dramatically and so have we. How we interpret and experience videogames, and the communities and cultures spawned from them, reveals much about how society has shifted in the past five decades.

results.title: Entities
results.creator_credit: Greg More (OOM Creative), James Sandri (MORE Studio), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio), MORE Studio and OOM Creative
results.brief_description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_primary.name: Future visions
constellations_primary.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Greg More (OOM Creative), James Sandri (MORE Studio), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio), MORE Studio and OOM Creative
results.description:
We leave a trace whenever we interact with a digital system: a thread of data that lingers like a ghost within a machine.

Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections. Each time an object is collected, the visualisation updates in real-time to create a dynamic living map of our visitors’ journey: the more people in the space, the more active it becomes. Created by code and contemporary web technologies, Entities encourages visitors to discover new objects and artworks by seeing what others are collecting in the gallery over time.
description_for_label:
We leave a trace whenever we interact with a digital system: a thread of data that lingers like a ghost within a machine.

Created by code and contemporary web technologies, Entities encourages visitors to discover new objects and artworks by seeing what others are collecting in the gallery over time.

results.title: Cyberthon Archives [documentation]
results.brief_description: Cyberthon was a series of TV broadcast events initiated in the 1990’s in Melbourne, Australia. This collection contains photographs, images and documentation that accompany the moving content in the archive.
results.description: Cyberthon was a series of TV broadcast events initiated in the 1990’s in Melbourne, Australia. This collection contains photographs, images and documentation that accompany the moving content in the archive.
description_for_label: Cyberthon was a series of TV broadcast events initiated in the 1990’s in Melbourne, Australia. This collection contains photographs, images and documentation that accompany the moving content in the archive.

results.title: Videogames supercut
results.brief_description: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups.

constellations_primary.name: Action, emotion and videogames
constellations_primary.description: More and more, videogames are beginning to favour emotion as much as action, just like their film and TV cousins.

results.description: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups. This video interweaves scenes from AAA, indie games and everything in-between to explore the emotional impact of games, as well as the white-knuckle tension of battle, how time can be manipulated for dramatic effect and how artistic expressions like movement and dance are bringing a human element to gaming.
description_for_label: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups. This video interweaves scenes from AAA, indie games and everything in-between to explore the emotional impact of games, as well as the white-knuckle tension of battle, how time can be manipulated for dramatic effect and how artistic expressions like movement and dance are bringing a human element to gaming.

results.title: Tomatoes for Troops
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane, Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit and Bob Harper
results.brief_description:
This film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, is an example of propaganda for the war effort, encouraging farmers to grow tomatoes for the armed forces during the Second World War. The film includes footage of soldiers on the Kokoda Trail, and outlines the importance of vegetables for the armed forces in combat overseas.

The film takes the viewer through the stages of tomato production on a mass scale, showing the process of collecting, disinfecting and washing seeds; cultivating and fertilising the soil; planting the seedlings and maximising growth. The film then outlines common diseases and pests that threaten the healthy growth of tomato plants, such as spotted wilt, tomato moths and weevils, along with preventative measures to mitigate these risks.

Finally, the film shows the industrial-scale quality assessment and canning of tomatoes in a factory. The final product, shown in the hands of an active soldier, is a can of SPC peeled tomatoes.

results.title: Melons for Jam
results.creator_credit: Ann Millard, Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This short film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, is an instructional film on fruit preserving. Expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates the process for making melon jam in a domestic kitchen. This film is a fascinating insight into household kitchens and cooking in the 1950s, particularly before widespread international food import enabled greater fruit produce availability all year.

results.title: Fashions for Men
results.creator_credit: Mel F. Nichols, Winifred Lade, Department of Information, Frank Coffey and John Maynard
results.brief_description: Produced by the Department of Information, this government propaganda film shows the manufacture of uniforms in factories for the Australian armed forces serving in the Second World War. The film begins with an opening sequence that chronicles the development of Australia’s armed forces since colonisation in 1788, showing the styles of uniform worn over the decades by soldiers making “glorious history”. The film then explores the mass production and assembly lines of the various equipment required for contemporary uniforms including silk parachutes, khaki wool clothing, brass badges, tin and felt hats, and gas masks. The film is a fascinating insight into factory production of the period, and an example of propaganda encouraging patriotic values in support of Australia’s armed forces. As with many instructional films of the period, the film reflects now outdated gender stereotypes, showing women working in assembly lines sewing on buttons, while men work with steel machinery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mel F. Nichols, Winifred Lade, Department of Information, Frank Coffey and John Maynard
